guiding_thinkers: Michel Foucault, Reinhart Koselleck, Quentin Skinner, Alasdair MacIntyre, Hayden White
description: Analyzes how an author's intellectual biography shapes their current work through genealogical tracing, conceptual history (Begriffsgeschichte), and Cambridge School contextualism. Treats ideas as historically contingent, path-dependent, and strategically managed.

assumptions: Ideas are historically contingent — they emerge from specific contexts and carry the marks of their origins
Intellectual evolution is path-dependent — prior commitments enable and constrain future positions
Authors manage their prior positions strategically, whether consciously or unconsciously
The relationship between an author's prior and current work is itself a text worth reading
Genealogy is not chronology — it traces conditions of possibility, not simple causation
Every intellectual position has an intellectual biography that shapes its meaning
core_tensions: Continuity vs Rupture — genuine development versus strategic rebranding
Enabling vs Constraining — prior work as resource versus prior work as limitation
Acknowledged vs Silent — transparent intellectual evolution versus managed history
Novel vs Path-dependent — genuinely new ideas versus recycled prior positions
scope_conditions: Requires access to the author's prior published works
Most effective when the author has a substantial body of prior work
Applies to intellectual rather than purely empirical claims
Benefits from knowledge of the broader intellectual context

primary_entities: Ideas — the theoretical positions, claims, and frameworks that constitute an author's intellectual output
Works — the published texts in which ideas appear and evolve
Evolution trajectories — the paths ideas take across an author's body of work
Tactics — the recurring patterns authors use to manage their prior positions
Conditions of possibility — the enabling and constraining factors created by prior work
relations: Genealogical trace — the connection between an idea in the current work and its precursor in prior work
Evolution — the transformation of an idea across multiple works
Enabling — how prior work makes current claims possible
Constraining — how prior commitments limit current positions
Tactical management — how the author handles the relationship between past and present positions
levels_of_analysis: Idea level — tracing the genealogy of individual concepts and claims
Work level — how each prior work contributes to the current argument
Career level — the overall arc of the author's intellectual development
Tactic level — the patterns of intellectual self-management

change_mechanisms: Conceptual drift — gradual, often unacknowledged shifts in meaning or emphasis
Framework migration — moving concepts from one theoretical home to another
Strategic reframing — consciously repositioning prior work to serve current arguments
Condition shift — changing the assessed world-situation while maintaining similar conclusions
Escalation — transforming tentative claims into established premises
temporal_patterns: Progressive development — ideas genuinely deepening over time
Cyclical return — returning to abandoned positions with new framing
Sharp reversal — dramatic changes of position
Teleological retrospection — retroactively narrating development as intentional
transformation_processes: Conceptual recycling — reusing old arguments in new frameworks
Narrative bootstrapping — using prior authority to support current speculation
Strategic amnesia — selectively forgetting inconvenient prior positions
Retroactive framing — presenting reactive evolution as directed development

key_concepts: Conditions of possibility — what makes a claim thinkable and assertable in a given intellectual context (Foucault)
Begriffsgeschichte — conceptual history tracing how the same term changes meaning across contexts (Koselleck)
Speech acts in context — understanding what an author is doing in saying what they say (Skinner)
Narrative identity — how an intellectual tradition constitutes itself through the stories it tells about its development (MacIntyre)
Emplotment — how historical narrative shapes the meaning of events through plot structure (White)
analytical_methods: Genealogical tracing — following ideas back through their prior appearances
Contextual reading — understanding claims in relation to the author's intellectual situation
Comparative analysis — placing prior and current versions side by side
Counterfactual analysis — asking what the argument would look like without the prior work history
Tactic identification — classifying the patterns of intellectual self-management
problem_diagnosis: Strategic amnesia — forgetting inconvenient prior positions
Narrative bootstrapping — trading on unearned authority
Silent revision — changing positions without acknowledgment
Escalation — inflating tentative claims without new evidence
Framework lock-in — being trapped by prior theoretical commitments
ideal_state: Transparent intellectual development — openly acknowledging how positions have changed and why
Productive path-dependence — prior work genuinely enriching rather than constraining current analysis
Reflexive self-genealogy — authors consciously mapping their own intellectual evolution
Intellectual honesty — acknowledging what was lost as well as what was gained in evolution

trait_definitions.trait_description: Following ideas back through their prior appearances to understand conditions of possibility
Reading claims in relation to the author's intellectual situation and prior commitments
Identifying the recurring patterns authors use to manage their intellectual history

critique_patterns.diagnostic: Author has changed position from prior work without acknowledging the shift
Author trading on authority earned in one domain to make claims in another
Author remembers convenient aspects of prior work while forgetting inconvenient ones
Author presents intellectual evolution as directed toward current position
critique_patterns.fix: Show how {prior_position} was not oriented toward {current_position} but was responsive to {original_context}

historical_context: Draws on Foucault's genealogical method (Nietzsche, Genealogy, History), Koselleck's Begriffsgeschichte (conceptual history), Skinner's Cambridge School contextualism (meaning and context of political texts), MacIntyre's narrative-based tradition analysis, and White's metahistorical analysis of narrative emplotment
